sub_topic: Lorentz transformation of coordinates and time
message_1: A spaceship is traveling at 0.8c relative to the Earth. The crew of the spaceship observes a stationary planet whose length in the direction of motion appears to be 40% shorter than its measured length on Earth. Determine the Lorentz factor, the time dilation factor, and the corresponding time elapsed on the planet according to the spaceship crew and on Earth according to an observer on Earth over a period of 10 years on Earth.
message_2:
To determine the Lorentz factor (γ), we can use the following formula:

γ = 1 / √(1 - v^2/c^2)

where v is the relative velocity of the spaceship (0.8c) and c is the speed of light. Plugging in the values:

γ = 1 / √(1 - (0.8c)^2/c^2)
γ = 1 / √(1 - 0.64)
γ = 1 / √(0.36)
γ = 1 / 0.6
γ ≈ 1.67

The Lorentz factor is approximately 1.67.

The time dilation factor is the same as the Lorentz factor, so the time dilation factor is also approximately 1.67.

Now, let's find the corresponding time elapsed on the planet according to the spaceship crew and on Earth according to an observer on Earth over a period of 10 years on Earth.

Time elapsed on Earth (t_Earth) = 10 years

Time elapsed on the spaceship (t_spaceship) = t_Earth / γ
t_spaceship = 10 years / 1.67
t_spaceship ≈ 6 years

So, over a period of 10 years on Earth, the spaceship crew would observe approximately 6 years elapsed on the planet.
